stream_context.summary: Kaze works on modeling a new forest/mushroom-themed area in the overworld. The stream is heavily impacted by his recent upgrade to Windows 11, leading him to struggle with new versions of Blender and search for a new image editor (trying Krita and GIMP) to process textures provided by Zeina. He also experiments with and critiques AI texture generation.

development_findings.summary: Luigi is planned to be added as a character, using a model by Pixelpalabra. This requires careful memory management, and Kaze plans to delete unused files to free up RAM on the N64.
development_findings.quote: I'm probably importing the Luigi this week. Maybe tomorrow I can start cleaning out some unused files in the RTY folders. And it will open up enough memory for Luigi to fit into RAM.

development_findings.summary: A key graphical technique used in the game is splitting surfaces into many small quads, allowing multiple different textures to be applied to a single logical surface to simulate higher texture detail.
development_findings.quote: So we can have multiple textures on them, which gives us a fake texture resolution that's way higher than what the N64 would normally be able to do.

development_findings.summary: Kaze tested an AI texture generator but found the results unusable due to a lack of seamlessness, poor art style, and low quality, concluding the technology is not viable for the project's standards.
development_findings.quote: I don't think AI texture generation is anywhere near the level where it can actually be used.

development_findings.summary: A critical and difficult step in the art pipeline is correctly handling the color of transparent pixels in textures to avoid ugly visual artifacts (like white or black outlines) caused by the N64's bilinear filtering.
development_findings.quote: In Photoshop this outline will always be black. And the only way to prevent the outline is to not use filtering on your textures.

development_findings.summary: Kaze uses a custom, in-development version of the Project64 emulator for testing, which features significant improvements like working audio.
development_findings.quote: I have a completely custom version of project 64 now. This is still in development. But it already has some neat improvements. The most important one is that the audio actually works.

development_findings.summary: The game is being optimized for real N64 hardware, with performance constantly being checked. In one test, enabling widescreen mode resulted in a minor FPS drop from 36 to 33.5.
The team's workflow is impacted by software updates; Kaze's recent switch to Blender 4.2 has caused a temporary slowdown as he adapts to new hotkeys and controls.
development_findings.quote: Getting used to a new software version like this is painful as hell. Like, oh my god. It is so annoying.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes corporate activism, such as for Pride Month, is meaningless lip service that only reflects what companies perceive to be the current, profitable societal consensus.
context_findings.quote: They project back to you what they think society already believes... It just tells you what they think you already think.

context_findings.summary: Kaze applies a strong rationalist and efficiency-oriented philosophy to his life, justifying a $600 robotic lawnmower by calculating the immense amount of personal time it saves over a lifetime.
context_findings.quote: You are 0.12% killing yourself by mowing the lawn instead of getting an automower.

context_findings.summary: Kaze stopped taking pre-workout supplements after realizing they were negatively impacting his mental clarity, demonstrating self-awareness about his physical and mental state.
context_findings.quote: It is crazy how I feel like I can speak and think so much clearer when I don't take pre-workout in the morning.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds the philosophy that practical application is the only real way to learn programming, dismissing formal education or books on the subject.
context_findings.quote: I'm of the opinion that programming is not something you learn. Or go to school for. It's something you just do.

context_findings.summary: A recent upgrade to Windows 11 has disrupted Kaze's workflow, forcing him to learn new software (Blender 4.2, DaVinci Resolve) and find replacements for essential tools like image editors.
Kaze is against forking software for the project, preferring to adapt to official updates to continue benefiting from the progress of the larger open-source community.
context_findings.quote: If we branch off blender now, we're not going to get new blender features. We're going to lose like 10,000 people contributing to the whole modeling program.

context_findings.summary: Kaze received a potential commission to create a 120-star ROM hack based on 'The Croods' for $5000, which he would plan to complete in about a month.

biobak.summary: Biobak is developing a level, tentatively named 'Dino Dino Domain', and has been sharing its progress with Kaze.
biobak.quote: Damn, I actually thought today would be the day we do Dino, Dino Domain or Divine Dino Domain. Biobak's been teasing me for a while.

biobak.summary: Biobak actively provides technical and artistic suggestions during development, such as proposing solutions for special lighting effects on actors.
biobak.quote: If it's for like a special effect, I can add an actual light coming from underneath instead of doing the ambient thing biopack.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the mushroom cluster art asset used for decals in the overworld, working directly from Kaze's request during the stream.
zeina.quote: You hear that, Zeina? Can you take the grass out of it? And just have a pile of mushrooms on transparent background? I think that is what we need.

zeina.summary: Zeina's initial texture included blue shadows, which Kaze questioned. She later provided a version without them, showing an iterative and responsive collaborative process.
zeina.quote: You put blue shadows on all of these, Zeina? That's a little weird and might ruin everything, but we'll try.

key_stories.title: The Search for a Photoshop Replacement
key_stories.summary: After a Windows 11 upgrade broke his software setup, Kaze needed a new image editor to process a texture from Zeina. He first tried Krita and found it inadequate for the specific needs of N64 development. He then switched to GIMP, and despite its 'cumbersome' workflow and bugs, he successfully prepared the asset, showcasing the technical hurdles of working with legacy hardware limitations.
key_stories.challenge: To process a texture from Zeina (index to 16 colors, set background color for alpha channel) without his usual image editing software after a Windows 11 upgrade.
key_stories.process: Kaze first downloaded and tested Krita based on chat's suggestion, but found it lacked the necessary color indexing functionality. He then downloaded GIMP, which he was more familiar with, and used it to create a background color layer, scale the image, and index the palette, working around a bug that exported the wrong number of colors.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully processed the texture using GIMP and imported it into the game. He concluded that Krita was unusable for his specific needs, and GIMP, while buggy and cumbersome, was the necessary tool for the job.
key_stories.key_quote: Krita is not usable. Krita doesn't have the features we need. I guess we have to download Gimp.

key_stories.title: The AI Texture Experiment
key_stories.summary: Needing a mushroom texture, Kaze was prompted by chat to try an AI generator. Despite refining his prompts, the AI produced unusable, non-seamless images that didn't fit the art style. The experiment reinforced Kaze's belief that AI is not yet a viable tool for this kind of creative work and also carries a 'debuff' due to negative community perception.
key_stories.challenge: To create a seamless, stylized mushroom floor texture for a new overworld area.
key_stories.process: At chat's suggestion, Kaze used an AI texture generator. He prompted it for a 'Seamless Mushroom Texture in a Stylized cartoonish art style,' then refined the prompt to be orthographic. He analyzed the results live, pointing out the lack of seamlessness, incorrect art style, and that the output was just an image, not a tileable texture.
key_stories.outcome: The AI failed to produce a usable texture. Kaze concluded the technology is not ready for professional game development and that using it would be detrimental due to community backlash. He moved on to a different solution using 3D decal objects.
key_stories.key_quote: I don't think AI texture generation is anywhere near the level where it can actually be used.

key_stories.title: Importing Luigi
key_stories.summary: Kaze decided to add Luigi to the game, using a model created by community member Pixelpalabra that matches the game's art style. This required planning to manage the N64's limited RAM, with Kaze scheduling a task to delete unused files to free up memory for the new character model.
key_stories.challenge: To add Luigi as a playable character without exceeding the N64's RAM limitations.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified a high-quality Luigi model made by community member Pixelpalabra that fit the game's art style. He announced his plan to import it and identified the necessary technical step: cleaning out unused files from the project to create enough space in memory.
key_stories.outcome: The plan is in place to add Luigi to the game. The work of cleaning unused project files and importing the new model is scheduled for the near future.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm probably importing the Luigi this week. Maybe tomorrow I can start cleaning out some unused files in the RTY folders. And it will open up enough memory for Luigi to fit into RAM.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned someone offered to pay him $5,000 to create a 120-star ROM hack based on the movie 'The Croods' within a month.
questions: Is this commission confirmed and what are the terms?
What is your creative process for a 'speedrun' major hack like this?
How would you balance this with your work on RTYI?
What are the comedic possibilities you see in a Croods-themed hack?

open_questions.context: Kaze and Zeina collaborated on a mushroom texture. Kaze noted Zeina's use of 'blue shadows' was 'a little weird,' indicating a difference in artistic approach before she sent a new version.
questions: Can you describe your collaborative workflow with Zeina on art assets?
How do you resolve minor creative differences, like the color of shadows on a texture?
How does your personal relationship dynamic influence the professional collaboration on the game?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that Biobak has been teasing him with a level called 'Dino Dino Domain' or 'Divine Dino Domain'.
questions: What is the concept and design philosophy behind Dino Dino Domain?
What is the collaborative process like for a level that Biobak is leading?
What stage of development is the level in and what are the next steps?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he is using a custom, in-development version of Project64 with features like improved audio.
questions: Who is developing this custom emulator version?
What are the specific technical improvements beyond audio?
How does this custom tool aid in the development and testing of RTYI compared to standard emulators?
